metadata.name: TOAST Scenario Cards
metadata.disclaimer: These scenarios are training exercises to help you think through emergency situations. They are not a substitute for professional emergency response training or real emergency services. Always contact appropriate authorities in actual emergencies.

entries.title: Extended Power Outage (24h)
entries.summary: Power is out across your city due to grid failure. No ETA on restoration.
entries.situation: Power is out across your city due to grid failure. No ETA on restoration.
immediate_risks: Loss of refrigeration and food spoilage
first_5_minutes: Check if outage is localized or widespread
Turn off major appliances to prevent power surge damage when electricity returns
Locate flashlights and emergency lighting
Check phone battery level and begin conservation mode
first_hour: Inventory perishable foods in refrigerator
Keep fridge and freezer doors closed to maintain temperature
Set up alternative lighting in key areas
Charge essential devices using any available power sources
Check on neighbors, especially elderly or those with medical needs
first_day: Prioritize eating foods that will spoil first
Move items from fridge to cooler if available
Conserve phone battery - use airplane mode when not needed
Stay informed via battery radio if available
Plan meals around shelf-stable foods
watch_for: Signs of heat exhaustion or hypothermia depending on season
Updates from utility companies or emergency services
notes: A full freezer can keep food frozen for 48 hours if door stays closed
Refrigerator keeps food safe for about 4 hours without power
Know which foods spoil first and consume those early

entries.title: Extended Power Outage (72h)
entries.summary: Power is out across your city due to grid failure. No ETA on restoration. Day 3.
entries.situation: Power has been out for 72 hours with no restoration timeline.
immediate_risks: Sanitation concerns without running water pumps
first_5_minutes: Assess remaining power reserves in devices
Check water supply status
Evaluate remaining food supplies
Determine if evacuation to powered location is necessary
first_hour: Discard any spoiled food to prevent illness
Ration remaining charged devices
Establish water conservation protocols
Connect with neighbors for resource sharing
first_day: Focus on shelf-stable meal planning
Minimize device usage to essential communications only
Establish routine using daylight hours
Consider alternative locations if situation becomes untenable
notes: After 72 hours, most perishables should be discarded
Community cooperation becomes increasingly important
Mental resilience and routine help maintain morale

entries.title: Extended Power Outage (7 Days)
entries.summary: Power is out across your city due to grid failure. No ETA on restoration. Week 1.
entries.situation: Power has been out for 7 days with no clear restoration timeline.
first_5_minutes: Evaluate whether staying in place is still viable
Check remaining food and water supplies
Assess security of current location
Consider evacuation options
first_hour: Take inventory of all remaining resources
Establish contact with support network if possible
Review evacuation routes and destinations
Secure your location if staying in place
first_day: Implement strict rationing of all supplies
Establish routine for water acquisition and treatment
Coordinate with neighbors for shared resources and security
Make decision about evacuation vs. shelter-in-place
watch_for: Signs of illness from poor sanitation
notes: Extended outages may require fundamental changes in daily routine
Community organization becomes critical
Have alternative locations and evacuation plans ready

entries.title: Water Service Interruption
entries.summary: Municipal water pressure drops or stops entirely.
entries.situation: Municipal water pressure drops or stops entirely.
immediate_risks: No water for drinking or sanitation
first_5_minutes: Fill bathtubs and large containers with any remaining water
Inventory all stored water
Stop all non-essential water use immediately
Check if neighbors are affected (local vs. widespread)
first_hour: Calculate how much potable water you have available
Identify nearby water sources (stores, natural sources)
Set up water conservation protocols
Designate water for drinking vs. sanitation
first_day: Ration water: drinking priority, hygiene second, sanitation third
Use greywater for toilet flushing if available
Seek information on water distribution points
Consider water treatment methods for alternative sources
watch_for: Water quality issues if using alternative sources
notes: Average person needs 1 gallon per day for drinking
Additional water needed for sanitation and cooking
Greywater from washing can be used for toilet flushing
Know how to treat water if using alternative sources

entries.title: Internet & Cell Network Down
entries.summary: Data and voice networks are down, SMS unreliable.
entries.situation: Data and voice networks are down, SMS unreliable.
immediate_risks: Emergency services may be unreachable by phone
first_5_minutes: Try to send SMS messages (may work when calls don't)
Check radio for information
Assess if this is local or widespread
Locate physical maps if navigation needed
first_hour: Make list of important contacts and their locations
Tune to local AM/FM radio stations for updates
Check if Wi-Fi networks are available
Consider physically checking on priority contacts
first_day: Establish routine check-in times at predetermined locations
Use battery-powered radio for information
Rely on face-to-face communication
Follow pre-established family emergency plans
watch_for: Official announcements via radio or public address
Network restoration (test periodically but conserve battery)
notes: SMS may work when voice calls don't
AM radio signals travel farther than FM
Having a predetermined rally point with family is crucial
Know how to access emergency services without cell phones

entries.title: Severe Storm / Tornado Warning
entries.summary: Tornado warning issued. 15 minutes until impact.
entries.situation: Tornado warning issued. 15 minutes until impact.
immediate_risks: Being caught outdoors or in vehicle
Power lines and gas leaks post-storm
first_5_minutes: Move immediately to the lowest level of your building
Get to an interior room away from windows (bathroom, closet, hallway)
If in a vehicle, do NOT try to outrun - seek shelter in a sturdy building
Grab emergency kit if immediately accessible
first_hour: Stay in shelter location until all-clear is given
Cover yourself with heavy blankets, sleeping bags, or mattress
Monitor weather radio or emergency alerts
After storm passes, wait for official all-clear before exiting
first_day: Once safe, check for injuries
Inspect home for damage: gas leaks, electrical hazards, structural issues
Avoid downed power lines
Take photos of damage for insurance
Check on neighbors
watch_for: Sound of freight train or sudden silence (tornado approaching)
notes: If no basement, go to center of lowest floor in interior room
Mobile homes are unsafe - seek alternative shelter
Highway overpasses are NOT safe shelter
Know the difference between watch (possible) and warning (happening now)

entries.title: Wildfire Evacuation
entries.summary: Mandatory evacuation in 30 minutes. Roads congested.
entries.situation: Mandatory evacuation in 30 minutes. Roads congested.
first_5_minutes: Start loading pre-packed bug-out bags into vehicle
Grab essential documents, medications, and phone chargers
Alert family members and ensure everyone is ready to leave
Do NOT wait to gather non-essentials
first_hour: Leave immediately via primary evacuation route
If primary route blocked, use predetermined alternate route
Stay low if driving through smoke (better air near ground)
Communicate your route and destination to out-of-area contact
Do not return for forgotten items
first_day: Proceed to designated evacuation center or pre-planned safe location
Check in with family and emergency contacts
Register with Red Cross or emergency services
Monitor official channels for re-entry information
Do NOT return until officially permitted
watch_for: Sudden wind changes (can change fire direction rapidly)
Signs of smoke inhalation: difficulty breathing, confusion
notes: Never wait until fire is visible to evacuate
Keep car windows closed and AC on recirculate in smoke
Have go-bag and important documents pre-packed
Know multiple evacuation routes from your area
Have out-of-area contact as communication hub

entries.title: Flash Flood
entries.summary: Sudden flooding after heavy rain. Roads underwater.
entries.situation: Sudden flooding after heavy rain. Roads underwater.
immediate_risks: Swift water can sweep away vehicles and people
first_5_minutes: Move to higher ground immediately
Do NOT attempt to cross flowing water on foot or in vehicle
If trapped in vehicle in rising water, exit immediately and move to roof
Stay away from downed power lines
first_hour: Continue moving to highest available ground
Stay out of floodwater (contains sewage, chemicals, debris)
Signal for help if stranded
Monitor weather radio for flash flood warnings
Do not return to home until water recedes and deemed safe
first_day: Wait for official all-clear before returning home
Document flood damage with photos
Do not walk through floodwater if avoidable
Check home for structural damage before entering
Discard any food that contacted floodwater
watch_for: Strong currents - even 6 inches can knock you over
Continued rain and potential for more flooding
Contamination and waterborne illness after flood
notes: Just 12 inches of water can carry away most vehicles
Never drive through flooded roads - turn around, don't drown
Floodwater may be contaminated with sewage
Most flood deaths occur in vehicles
Flash floods can occur within minutes of heavy rain

entries.title: Extreme Heat Wave
entries.summary: Power out + 110°F+ temperatures.
entries.situation: Power is out during extreme heat, temperatures exceeding 110°F.
first_5_minutes: Move to coolest area of home (basement if available)
Close blinds and curtains to block sun
Start drinking water before you feel thirsty
Remove or loosen tight clothing
first_hour: Take cool (not cold) shower or bath if water available
Apply wet towels to neck, wrists, ankles
Limit physical activity
Check on elderly, young children, and those with medical conditions
Move pets to coolest area with access to water
first_day: Stay hydrated: drink water regularly even if not thirsty
Seek cooling centers or public buildings with AC if available
Avoid going outside during hottest parts of day (10am-4pm)
Eat small, light meals
Monitor yourself and others for signs of heat illness
watch_for: Heat exhaustion signs: heavy sweating, weakness, dizziness, nausea
Heat stroke signs: no sweating, confusion, rapid pulse, loss of consciousness
Dehydration: dry mouth, dark urine, fatigue
Pets showing distress: excessive panting, drooling, lethargy
notes: Heat stroke is life-threatening - call 911 if someone stops sweating during heat
Fans are ineffective above 95°F and may increase dehydration
Elderly, very young, and those on certain medications are at highest risk
Never leave pets in vehicles even briefly
Wet clothing and air flow help cool through evaporation

entries.title: Serious Injury, No EMS
entries.summary: Someone has a deep laceration. EMS unavailable.
entries.situation: Someone has a deep laceration and EMS is unavailable.
first_5_minutes: Apply direct pressure to wound with clean cloth
Have injured person lie down to prevent shock
Do NOT remove embedded objects
Elevate injury above heart if possible (and no fracture suspected)
first_hour: Maintain continuous direct pressure for 10-15 minutes
If bleeding soaks through, add more cloth on top (don't remove original)
Watch for signs of shock: pale skin, rapid pulse, confusion
If severe bleeding continues despite pressure, consider tourniquet (last resort)
Keep person warm with blanket
first_day: Once bleeding controlled, clean wound gently with clean water
Apply antibiotic ointment if available
Cover with sterile bandage
Monitor for infection: increased pain, redness, swelling, warmth, or pus
Keep wound clean and dry
Seek medical care as soon as it becomes available
watch_for: Continued heavy bleeding despite direct pressure
Signs of shock: pale/clammy skin, rapid breathing, weakness, confusion
Loss of feeling or movement near wound
Signs of infection: fever, red streaks from wound, pus, worsening pain
Wound not showing signs of healing
notes: Direct pressure stops most bleeding
Tourniquets are for life-threatening limb bleeding only
Never remove embedded objects - stabilize them in place
Human bite wounds have high infection risk
Deep wounds may require stitches within 6-8 hours for best healing
When in doubt, seek professional medical care

entries.title: Prescription Disruption
entries.summary: Pharmacy access cut off for 7 days.
entries.situation: Pharmacy access cut off for 7 days due to emergency.
first_5_minutes: Inventory all medications and their quantities
Calculate how many days each medication will last
Identify which medications are absolutely critical
Check if any family members or neighbors have same medications
first_hour: Call pharmacy or use app to request emergency refills if possible
Contact your doctor about missed doses and alternatives
Research if any medications can be temporarily substituted or doses reduced safely
Check for 24-hour pharmacies or hospital pharmacies that may be accessible
first_day: Prioritize critical medications (heart, diabetes, seizure, blood thinners, etc.)
For less critical medications, consider if temporary discontinuation is safe
Never share prescription medications with others
Document any changes in condition related to missed medications
Continue seeking access to pharmacy or medical care
watch_for: Withdrawal symptoms from suddenly stopping medications
Seizure activity if on anti-seizure medications
notes: Some medications are dangerous to stop suddenly - never stop without medical advice
Critical medications: insulin, heart medications, seizure medications, blood thinners
Keep a 30-day supply of all medications if possible
Know generic names of your medications (useful when seeking alternatives)
Hospital emergency rooms can provide emergency refills of critical medications
Many pharmacies can transfer prescriptions in emergencies

entries.title: Infectious Illness in Household
entries.summary: One person becomes highly contagious.
entries.situation: One household member becomes highly contagious.
first_5_minutes: Move ill person to separate room if possible
Ensure ill person wears mask when around others
Open windows for ventilation if weather permits
Wash hands thoroughly
first_hour: Designate separate bathroom for ill person if possible
Gather supplies for ill person (tissues, trash bag, water, medications)
Remove shared items from sick room (books, electronics)
Establish schedule for checking on ill person while minimizing contact
All household members should wear masks when interacting with ill person
first_day: Maintain isolation protocols
Disinfect high-touch surfaces regularly (doorknobs, light switches, counters)
Use separate dishes/utensils for ill person or use disposables
Handle ill person's laundry separately with hot water
Dispose of tissues and trash carefully using gloves
Monitor other household members for symptoms
watch_for: Symptoms appearing in other household members
Difficulty breathing or high fever requiring medical attention
notes: Ventilation is critical - open windows if possible
Wear mask and gloves when cleaning sick areas
Wash hands frequently with soap for 20+ seconds
Disinfect surfaces ill person touches
Keep ill person hydrated and rested
Seek medical care if condition worsens
Some illnesses contagious before symptoms appear

entries.title: Civil Unrest / Riots Nearby
entries.summary: Protests escalate near your neighborhood.
entries.situation: Protests escalate near your neighborhood.
first_5_minutes: Monitor news and social media for real-time updates
Assess how close the unrest is to your location
Decide quickly: shelter in place or relocate to safer area
Bring family members inside immediately
first_hour: If sheltering in place: lock all doors and windows
Close curtains and blinds
Move to interior rooms away from windows
Avoid posting on social media that could draw attention to your location
Have bug-out bag ready in case you need to evacuate quickly
first_day: Keep low profile - lights minimal at night
Monitor situation constantly but don't go outside to observe
Avoid confrontation if approached
Maintain communication with family, friends, and neighbors
Stay away from windows
Have emergency route planned if evacuation becomes necessary
watch_for: Unrest spreading closer to your location
Fire or smoke in the area
Groups of people moving through neighborhood
Sounds of violence or property destruction
notes: Most civil unrest stays in commercial areas, but can spread
Do not attempt to defend property at risk of personal safety
Avoid drawing attention to your home (lights, sounds)
If you must evacuate, have a pre-planned route and destination
Do not share real-time location on social media during crisis
Cooperate with authorities
Insurance can replace property - stay safe

entries.title: Shelter-in-Place Order
entries.summary: Authorities order residents indoors for unknown reasons.
entries.situation: Authorities order residents indoors for unknown reasons.
first_5_minutes: Get inside immediately
Bring pets inside
Lock all doors and windows
Turn on TV or radio for official information
first_hour: Seal windows and doors with plastic and tape if air contamination is concern
Turn off ventilation systems that bring in outside air
Gather all household members in interior room
Inventory food, water, and essential supplies
Charge all electronic devices
first_day: Stay indoors and away from windows
Monitor official channels for updates and instructions
Verify information sources - beware of rumors
Conserve food and water until duration is known
Maintain routine to manage stress
Keep children and pets calm and occupied
watch_for: Official updates on the nature of the threat
Evacuation orders (be ready to leave quickly if ordered)
Changes in air quality or unusual smells (chemical threat)
notes: Shelter-in-place orders usually have specific duration or threat
For chemical threats, interior room on upper floor is often safest
For radiation: basement or center of building
Trust official sources over rumors
Have physical copies of emergency contact numbers
Follow official instructions exactly
Do not leave until authorities say it's safe

entries.title: Stranded Away From Home
entries.summary: You're 25 miles from home when transport shuts down.
entries.situation: You're 25 miles from home when all transportation suddenly shuts down.
immediate_risks: Long distance to cover on foot
first_5_minutes: Stop and assess the situation
Check your phone for information and map your location
Inventory what you have with you (water, food, cash, charger)
Contact family to let them know your situation and plan
first_hour: Decide: wait for transport to resume or start walking home
If walking: plan route using offline maps or landmarks you know
Conserve phone battery (airplane mode, reduce brightness)
Look for sheltering options: stores, libraries, churches
Team up with others heading same direction if safe to do so
first_day: If walking: pace yourself, take breaks, stay hydrated
Walk on populated roads when possible for safety
In darkness, prioritize safety over speed - consider sheltering until daylight
Use landmarks and main roads for navigation
Avoid shortcuts through isolated areas
Seek temporary shelter if weather is dangerous
watch_for: Opportunities for safe shelter or assistance
notes: Average person walks 3 mph - 25 miles is 8+ hours of walking
Walking at night is more dangerous - weigh the risks
Main roads safer than shortcuts through unfamiliar areas
Know major landmarks and roads to navigate without GPS
Keep everyday carry bag (EDC) with basics: water, snacks, charger, cash
Churches, fire stations, and police stations may offer shelter
Working together with others is safer but choose companions carefully

entries.title: Lost While Hiking
entries.summary: Trail markers disappear. Nightfall in 2 hours.
entries.situation: Trail markers disappear. Nightfall in 2 hours.
immediate_risks: Hypothermia when temperature drops at night
first_5_minutes: STOP - don't panic and don't wander aimlessly
Check your phone for GPS signal or offline maps
Look for high ground to get your bearings
Assess what supplies you have
first_hour: If you know general direction to trailhead and it's safe, proceed carefully
If unsure, stay put - rescuers will backtrack your route
Find or create shelter before dark
Signal location: whistle, mirror, bright clothing visible from above
Conserve phone battery but use it to try to contact help
first_day: If staying put: improve shelter, gather materials for warmth
Stay hydrated - find water source if needed
Create signal: three of anything (rocks, piles, fires) means distress
Make noise periodically (whistle, yell) to help rescuers find you
Stay visible from air if possible
Conserve energy
watch_for: Signs of hypothermia: shivering, confusion, slurred speech
notes: Most lost hikers are found within 24 hours
Staying put is usually safer than wandering when truly lost
Three whistle blasts is universal distress signal
Shelter and warmth are top priorities as night approaches
Water from streams should be treated/filtered but dehydration is immediate risk
Tell someone your plans before hiking (who, where, when back)
Carry 10 essentials: navigation, sun protection, insulation, illumination, first aid, fire, repair kit, nutrition, hydration, emergency shelter

entries.title: Vehicle Breakdown in Remote Area
entries.summary: Car disabled, no cell signal.
entries.situation: Car disabled in remote area with no cell signal.
first_5_minutes: Turn on hazard lights if battery has power
Try cell phone - even weak signal may allow SOS call
Assess your situation: where are you, how far to help, what supplies do you have
Decide: stay with vehicle or walk for help
first_hour: In most cases: STAY WITH VEHICLE - it's easier to find than a person
Vehicle provides shelter from weather
Set out visible signals: hood up, bright cloth tied to antenna, SOS in rocks
Inventory all supplies: water, food, clothing, tools
Ration what you have
first_day: Continue signaling: honk horn periodically, flash lights at night
Conserve water - drink small amounts regularly
Stay in shade during hot weather, use car for shelter at night
If you have enough water, write HELP in large letters on ground using rocks or branches
Only leave vehicle if you're certain help is close and you have supplies to get there
watch_for: Signs of approaching vehicles or aircraft
Signs of dehydration: dry mouth, dark urine, dizziness
Hypothermia or heat exhaustion depending on conditions
notes: Vehicle is your best shelter and most visible signal
Most people can survive 3 days without water, 3 weeks without food
Walking for help is risky - only do if you're certain of location and distance
Mirror or shiny object can signal aircraft from miles away
Running engine for heat uses fuel - only run periodically, watch for carbon monoxide
Never run engine in enclosed space
Tell someone your route and expected arrival time before traveling remote areas

entries.title: Information Overload
entries.summary: Conflicting reports from radio, neighbors, social media.
entries.situation: Conflicting reports from multiple sources during crisis.
immediate_risks: Making wrong decision based on bad information
first_5_minutes: Stop consuming all sources momentarily
Take deep breaths to reduce stress response
Identify what decisions need to be made right now vs. later
Write down what you know for certain
first_hour: Prioritize official sources: emergency management, police, government
Cross-check information across multiple credible sources
Distinguish between facts and speculation
Ignore rumors and unverified social media posts
Focus on information relevant to your safety decisions
first_day: Establish routine for checking official sources at set intervals
Limit social media consumption - it amplifies fear and misinformation
Verify information before sharing or acting on it
Trust direct observations when possible
Make decisions based on best available information, not perfect information
Accept that some uncertainty is unavoidable
watch_for: Emotional manipulation in messages (designed to provoke fear or anger)
Sources that confirm what you already believe (confirmation bias)
Information that seems too good or too bad to be true
Your own decision-making capability declining from stress
notes: In crisis, misinformation spreads faster than facts
Official sources may be slower but are more reliable
Perfect information is rarely available - make best decision with what you have
Rumors multiply during communication blackouts
Verify before you trust, especially on social media
Ask: Who said this? How do they know? What's their source?
Taking action on incomplete information is often better than paralysis
Limit news consumption to reduce anxiety while staying informed

entries.title: Group Conflict Over Limited Supplies
entries.summary: Limited supplies causing tension among people.
entries.situation: Limited supplies causing tension among people sheltering together.
first_5_minutes: Acknowledge the problem openly before it escalates
Call a group meeting in calm moment, not during argument
Take inventory of all supplies together transparently
Let everyone see what's available
first_hour: Establish fair rationing system together
Account for special needs (medical conditions, children)
Assign roles - who manages food, water, etc.
Create schedule for distribution
Get agreement from everyone on the system
Write down the plan
first_day: Follow the agreed-upon system consistently
Hold daily brief check-ins to address concerns early
Recognize everyone's contributions
Share tasks and responsibilities equally
Maintain transparency about supplies
Adjust system if fair issues arise
Keep focus on common goal: everyone's survival
notes: Fairness and transparency prevent most conflicts
Establish rules before scarcity becomes critical
Everyone needs to feel heard and respected
Children and those with medical needs may require different portions
Keep group cohesion - survival odds better together
Document decisions to prevent disputes about what was agreed
Leadership role may need to rotate to maintain trust
Address conflicts early before they escalate
Focus on objective criteria for rationing, not personal preferences

entries.title: Gas Smell
entries.summary: You smell gas but can't confirm the source.
entries.situation: You smell gas but can't confirm the source.
first_5_minutes: DO NOT use anything that could create spark: light switches, phones, appliances
Open windows and doors immediately
Evacuate building immediately
Once outside and safe distance away, call gas company and 911
first_hour: Stay away from building until professionals clear it
Do not re-enter to get belongings
Alert neighbors to stay away
Wait for gas company to inspect and clear
notes: Natural gas is lighter than air - rises up
Propane is heavier than air - sinks to low spots
Gas companies add smell to normally odorless gas

entries.title: Someone Asking for Water
entries.summary: Someone knocks asking for water.
entries.situation: Someone knocks asking for water during emergency.
first_5_minutes: Assess situation from safe position - don't open door immediately
Evaluate: Do you know them? Do they appear genuinely in need? Are they alone?
Consider your own supply situation
first_hour: If helping: provide water through closed door or in neutral location, don't invite inside
If declining: be firm but not confrontational
Consider directing them to official aid locations if you know of any
watch_for: Multiple people when one appeared first
Attempts to see inside your home
notes: Your first duty is to your household's survival
Trust your instincts about safety
Consider community aid if you have surplus, but protect your security

entries.title: Unexplained Sirens
entries.summary: You hear sirens approaching but no official alerts.
entries.situation: You hear sirens approaching but no official alerts on phone or media.
immediate_risks: Being in the way of emergency vehicles
first_5_minutes: Look outside safely to assess situation
Check local news, social media, and emergency apps
If sirens are close and continuous, move away from windows
first_hour: Monitor situation without putting yourself at risk
Be ready to evacuate if situation warrants
Clear any vehicles from street if emergency vehicles need access
watch_for: Police or fire activity in area
notes: Sirens usually indicate localized emergency
Stay out of the way of emergency responders
Be ready to follow any instructions from authorities

entries.title: Flashlight Dies
entries.summary: Your flashlight dies unexpectedly in darkness.
entries.situation: Your flashlight dies unexpectedly in darkness.
first_5_minutes: Stop moving immediately to prevent injury
Let eyes adjust to darkness (takes several minutes)
Try phone light if available (conserve battery)
Feel your way to safe location
first_hour: Replace batteries if available
Create improvised lighting (phone, glow sticks, candles if safe)
Stay put until you have safe lighting if in dangerous area
notes: Always carry backup batteries and backup light source
Phone can be emergency light but drains battery
Eyes adjust to darkness in 20-30 minutes
Peripheral vision better than direct in low light

entries.title: Pet Panics in Storm
entries.summary: Your pet panics during a storm.
entries.situation: Your pet panics during a storm.
first_5_minutes: Secure pet in safe interior room away from windows
Close doors and secure exits so pet can't escape
Speak calmly and reassuringly
Remove pet from stimuli if possible (close curtains, reduce noise)
first_hour: Stay with pet if safe to do so
Provide familiar comfort items (favorite blanket, toy)
Consider covering crate with blanket to create den-like space
Keep pet leashed if they might bolt
watch_for: Signs of injury from panic (scratches, broken nails)
Refusal to eat or drink (stress response)
Attempts to hide in dangerous locations
notes: Never leave panicked pet loose during storm - they may run
Have pet emergency kit ready: leash, carrier, food, meds, records
Some pets respond well to anxiety wraps or calming music
Your calm behavior helps calm your pet
Include pets in evacuation plans - never leave them behind
